title: Fight Club
author: Chuck Palahniuk
notes: Loved the movie. The book was pretty good too.

title: Rich Dad Poor Dad
author: Robert T. Kiyosaki
notes: I read this a long time ago when I was learning about personal finance. I recall liking it, but not loving it.

title: Perfume
author: Patrick Suskind
notes: A dark, twisted story that I enjoyed. The movie was great too!

title: The Strain
author: Derek Sivers
notes: Somewhat entertaining, but not good enough to bother with the trilogy. And I didn't watch the show either.

title: Testimony
author: Robbie Robertson
notes: I love The Band and I really enjoyed this book. What a life!

title: Useful Not True
author: Derek Sivers
notes: Another great book from Sivers.

title: How to Live: 27 conflicting answers and one weird conclusion
author: Derek Sivers
notes: A weird book, but I like weird.

title: Hell Yeah or No: what’s worth doing
author: Derek Sivers
notes: I'm a fan of Sivers and I can't say enough good things about him and everything he does.

title: Stillness is the Key
author: Ryan Holiday
notes: I was a big fan of The Obstacle is the Way and Ego is the Enemy, but this one was bad. It felt shallow and empty of anything useful. It put me off Ryan Holiday books.

title: The Millionaire Next Door: The Surprising Secrets of America's Wealthy
author: Thomas J. Stanley Ph.D & William D. Danko Ph.D
notes: Very, very interesting book about millionaires. Who knew that living a modest, frugal life could lead to being a millionaire.

title: Between a Rock and a Hard Place
author: Aron Ralston
notes: I wasn't expecting much from this book, but I was exceptionally surprised. It was great!

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
author: Ken Kesey
notes: I recall being bored and depressed while reading this book.

title: American Sniper
author: Chris Kyle & Scott McEwen & Jim DeFelice
notes: Read this because of the title and it was good. Then the movie was released and I also liked that too.

title: Angela's Ashes
author: Frank McCourt
notes: What a sad, but humorous story. Makes me feel very grateful for what I have.

title: Tis: A Memoir
author: Frank McCourt
notes: Not as good as Angela's Ashes, but still a good read.

title: Blisters and Bliss: A Trekker's Guide to the West Coast Trail
author: David Foster & Wayne Aitken & Nelson Dewey
notes: I picked this one up when I was thinking about hiking the WCT. I will probably revisit it in a couple of years.

title: Lost in the Barrens
author: Farley Mowat
notes: I loved this book as a teenager. Can't wait to share it with my kids.

title: The Scarlet Plague
author: Jack London
notes: A scary apocalyptic book. I often think about how it comes down to brute strength in survival situations like this. I don't stand a chance.

title: White Fang
author: Jack London
notes: A great follow up to Call of the Wild.

title: The Call of the Wild
author: Jack London
notes: Very good adventure book that I thought was really sad.

title: The Wolf of Wall Street
author: Jordan Belfort
notes: Usually the book is better than the movie, but I think this time it's reversed.

title: The Road
author: Cormac McCarthy
notes: A unique writing style that I really enjoyed. The movie was great too.

title: I Will Teach You To Be Rich
author: Ramit Sethi
notes: A good one amongst all the personal finance book out there.

title: Wiseguy
author: Nicholas Pileggi
notes: A must read for any fans of Goodfellas.

title: Clockwork Orange
author: Anthony Burgess
notes: A strange book that is tough to read and understand.

title: No One Here Gets Out Alive
author: Jerry Hopkins & Danny Sugerman
notes: These rockstars live alien lives.

title: Exile on Main Street: A Season in Hell with the Rolling Stones
author: Robert Greenfield
notes: Not a huge fan of the stones, but I found this to be an interesting read. Like I said before, these guys live alien lives.

title: No Surrender: My Thirty-Year War
author: SEstate of Hiroo Onoda
notes: Crazy story of a brainwashed solider.

title: The Shining
author: Stephen King
notes: Classic King!

title: Think And Grow Rich
author: Napoleon Hill
notes: One of the very first self-development books I read.

title: Vagabonding: An Uncommon Guide to the Art of Long-Term World Travel
author: Rolf Potts
notes: Interesting, but not conducive to having kids.

title: Eat That Frog!: 21 Great Ways to Stop Procrastinating and Get More Done in Less Time
author: Brian Tracy
notes: A solid list of great productivity advice.

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
notes: This is one to keep on the bookshelf and reread every couple of years.

title: Moonwalking with Einstein: The Art and Science of Remembering Everything
author: Joshua Foer
notes: Very odd and entertaining.

title: How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia
author: Mohsin Hamid
notes: Recommended by Tim Ferriss. It was ok.

title: Understanding Exposure, Fourth Edition: How to Shoot Great Photographs with Any Camera
author: Bryan Peterson
notes: This book was a huge help when I was learning photography.

title: Choose Yourself!
author: James Altucher
notes: I think this book was $1 in the kindle store. It was good, and I even listened to James's podcast for a bit.

title: The Billionaire Who Wasn't: How Chuck Feeney Secretly Made and Gave Away a Fortune
author: Conor O'Clery
notes: The title of this one got me - I had to read it. Interesting story about duty-free and Chuck Feeney. It's hard to imagine having so much money that you need systematically plan spending.

title: MoneySense Guide to the Perfect Portfolio
author: Dan Bortolotti
notes: This guide was a big help when I started researching personal finance and investing. The book is no longer in print, but the author has been known to email copies if you reach out.

title: Ted Talks: The Official TED Guide to Public Speaking
author: Chris Anderson
notes: I read this to improve my public speaking at toastmasters. It's a gold mine of public speaking advice!

title: How to Fail at Almost Everything and Still Win Big: Kind of the Story of My Life
author: Scott Adams
notes: This was a great book and I did recommend it to several friends. Love the part about systems over goals. Definitely worth a re-read.

title: The Religion War
author: Scott Adams
notes: A sequel to God's debris. Probably worth a re-read since Mr.Adam's death.

title: The Religion War
author: Scott Adams
notes: An interesting thought experiment.

title: Churchill
author: Paul Johnson
notes: A short but sweet bio on Churchill. Two world wars, a painter, prolific writer, a mason, etc - the man is a legend.

title: Socrates: A Man for Our Times
author: Paul Johnson
notes: A short but sweet bio on Socrates.

title: Napoleon: A Life
author: Paul Johnson
notes: A short but sweet bio on Napoleon.

title: Mozart: A Life
author: Paul Johnson
notes: A short but sweet bio on Mozart.

title: Darwin: Portrait of a Genius
author: Paul Johnson
notes: A short but sweet bio on Darwin.

title: Life
author: Keith Richards
notes: Reading this was like reading about an alien - such a wild life.

title: Clapton: The Autobiography
author: Eric Clapton
notes: Didn't realize Clapton was a severe alcoholic for many years. It seems like he skimmed over how he learned to play the guitar which was a disappointment. I really wanted to read about that.

title: Alive
author: Piers Paul Read
notes: What a book! An amazing account of survival. I often think about the crew that hiked out to find help. They had little supplies or gear and crossed many mountains in the cold - it's just amazing and inspirational.

title: Hitler's Last Witness: The Memoirs of Hitler's Bodyguard
author: Rochus Misch
notes: An interesting perspective from a man who was around Hitler everyday while he was in power.

title: Discipline Equals Freedom: Field Manual
author: Jocko Willink
notes: A very simple book.

title: The Gift of Failure: How the Best Parents Learn to Let Go So Their Children Can Succeed
author: Jessica Lahey
notes: I read this two years after my daughter was born. Let your kids fuck up and figure it - very good advice for parents.

title: Tribe: On Homecoming and Belonging
author: Sebastian Junger
notes: I listened to a promotional podcast that Junger did for this book, so I decided to read it. There's some interesting ideas in here.

title: Ordinary Men: Reserve Police Battalion 101 and the Final Solution in Poland
author: Christopher R. Browning
notes: Recommended by JP. A haunting account of the worst things people will do when there is group pressure and the interesting effect it had on the perpetrators. I think about this book often.

title: Choke
author: Chuck Palahniuk
notes: I didn't get this book.

title: I Can't Make This Up: Life Lessons
author: Kevin Hart
notes: I read this because it was on sale for a $1 in the kindle store. For not knowing anything about Kevin Hart or not being a fan, this book turned me into a fan. I watched his first comedy special after reading this and it was hilarious.

title: The Grumpy Accountant: One Fed-Up Tax Pro's Practical Plan to Fix Canada's Senselessly Complicated Tax System
author: Neal Winokur
notes: Interesting insight, a little boring though. It's about what you think it would be for a book about taxes.

title: The Almanack of Naval Ravikant: A Guide to Wealth and Happiness
author: Eric Jorgenson
notes: There's something about Naval that is off. Not sure what it is, but I don't like it. I am not a fan of these guru silicon valley types. With that being said, there is some good wisdom in these pages.

title: The Count of Monte Cristo
author: Alexandre Dumas
notes: This story is great. As I was reading the book, I wondered how someone in the 1800s wrote and organized the book. It's 700 pages and the story is very complex! Amazing work!

title: Shop Class as Soulcraft: An Inquiry into the Value of Work
author: Matthew B. Crawford
notes: Almost a continuation of Motorcycle maintenance. As someone who has one foot in knowledge work and the other foot in manual labor, this book did resonate.

title: Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance: An Inquiry into Values
author: Robert M. Pirsig
notes: This book has so many gems. I still don't fully understand the entire book, but there are parts of it that have stuck with me for years. The classical vs romantic thinker is something that is so true. I might have to revisit this one again soon.

title: The Automatic Millionaire
author: David Bach
notes: I loved this book. Very basic financial advice, but I loved the idea of automating it.

title: The Richest Man In Babylon
author: George S Clason
notes: Another one of those financial books that are on a lot of must-read lists. It was ok.

title: Empire of the Summer Moon
author: S. C. Gwynne
notes: Reading books like this make me realize how lucky I am to be living now rather than in times of extreme violence. This book is very graphic, but it's an interesting story. I read it after listening to an interview with the author on the JRE.

title: The Rape of Nanking: The Forgotten Holocaust Of World War II
author: Iris Chang
notes: It's insane what people can do to one another. This book shook me and I still think about it regularly. It will shake the naivety right out of you. Read with caution.

title: Reboot Your Portfolio: 9 Steps to Successful Investing with ETFs
author: Dan Bortolotti
notes: I read this because I am a fan of the author, but truth be told, it was boring. And it was the same old advice.

title: Do the Work: Overcome Resistance and Get Out of Your Own Way
author: Steven Pressfield
notes: Fight the resistance! Another motivating book from Pressfield.

title: The Wealthy Barber Returns
author: David Chilton
notes: This is one of the first personal finance books that I ever read. It left me with a lot of questions, but it also put me on the road to learning a lot more about money.

title: The Wealthy Barber: The Common Sense Guide to Successful Financial Planning
author: David Chilton
notes: This is one of the first personal finance books that I ever read. It left me with a lot of questions, but it also put me on the road to learning a lot more about money.

title: 12 Rules for Life: An Antidote to Chaos
author: Jordan B. Peterson
notes: I know that JP is controversial, but this book is great. I think about this book a lot.

title: Beyond Order: 12 More Rules for Life
author: Jordan B. Peterson
notes: Just as good as the first book.

title: American Predator: The Hunt for the Most Meticulous Serial Killer of the 21st Century
author: Maureen Callahan
notes: In my mind, one of the most terrifying serial killers. Make you wonder how many of these psychos are out there hunting.

title: A Guide to the Good Life: The Ancient Art of Stoic Joy
author: William B Irvine
notes: A great introduction to stoicism. A book everybody should read.

title: Too Soon Old, Too Late Smart: Thirty True Things You Need to Know Now
author: Gordon Livingston MD
notes: This one didn't resonate with me. I can't recall any of the things I need to know now.

title: Animal Farm
author: George Orwell
notes: A strange way to learn about communism.

author: George Orwell
notes: A scary book. The torture part has always stuck with me - any man will break under those conditions.

title: Into Thin Air
author: Jon Krakauer
notes: McCandless was a pure romantic. I appreciate his passion for adventure, but he made some dumb mistakes.

title: Missoula: Rape and the Justice System in a College Town
author: Jon Krakauer
notes: Books like this are unnerving, especially having a daughter.

title: Under the Banner of Heaven: A Story of Violent Faith
author: Jon Krakauer
notes: Didn't expect to receive a history lesson on the Mormon faith, but it was interesting nonetheless.

title: Where Men Win Glory: The Odyssey of Pat Tillman
author: Jon Krakauer
notes: Just an absolute fantastic story.

title: Into Thin Air
author: Jon Krakauer
notes: I never want to climb Mount Everest after reading this book.

title: A Game of Thrones
author: George R. R. Martin
notes: This whole series was great and I loved the HBO series too.

title: A Clash of Kings
author: George R. R. Martin
notes: This whole series was great and I loved the HBO series too.

title: A Storm of Swords
author: George R. R. Martin
notes: This whole series was great and I loved the HBO series too.

title: A Feast for Crows
author: George R. R. Martin
notes: This whole series was great and I loved the HBO series too.

title: A Dance with Dragons
author: George R. R. Martin
notes: This whole series was great and I loved the HBO series too.

title: Once Upon a Time in Hollywood
author: Quentin Tarantino
notes: The film was focused on Rick Dalton while the book is more focused on Cliff. I hope a spinoff is made about Cliff.

title: The Postmortal
author: Drew Magary
notes: Recommended by a friend. It was very entertaining.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
notes: A big fan of the series and films.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
notes: A big fan of the series and films.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
notes: A big fan of the series and films.

title: The Practicing Mind: Developing Focus and Discipline in Your Life — Master Any Skill or Challenge by Learning to Love the Process
author: Thomas M. Sterner
notes: A book that taught me to be patient and smile while I am learning new skills.

title: Why We Sleep: Unlocking the Power of Sleep and Dreams
author: Matthew Walker
notes: I listened to Matthew Walker on the JRE and it blew my mind! I ordered the book and was blown away while reading it. For over 30 years of my life I knew nothing about the science of sleep and I was doing so many things wrong. This book changed my life for the better. Highly recommended!

title: American Kingpin: The Epic Hunt for the Criminal Mastermind Behind the Silk Road
author: Nick Bilton
notes: Highly entertaining! I was amazed at what Ulbricht was able to build in terms of coding it without the skills - he just went at it. I think Trump just pardoned him.

title: Out of Your Mind: Tricksters, Interdependence, and the Cosmic Game of Hide-and-Seek
author: Alan Watts
notes: I don't remember anything Watts said, I just enjoy listening to him talk.

title: Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking
author: Susan Cain
notes: As an introvert I loved this book. It gave me the confidence to embrace my personality and be ok with saying less. It's also a good book for extroverted people wanting to learn more about their opposites.

title: The Willpower Instinct: How Self-Control Works, Why It Matters, and What You Can Do to Get More of It
author: Kelly McGonigal
notes: Probably a good book for everyone to read.

title: Total Recall: My Unbelievably True Life Story
author: Arnold Schwarzenegger
notes: What a life! I found the section on politics a little boring.

title: Benjamin Franklin: An American Life
author: Walter Isaacson
notes: Seems like BF was a very smart man. He lived quite the life.

title: The Rise of Superman: Decoding the Science of Ultimate Human Performance
author: Steven Kotler
notes: Recommended by a friend.

title: The War of Art: Break Through the Blocks and Win Your Inner Creative Battles
author: Steven Pressfield
notes: This book kicked me in the teeth. All the talk about resistance when I was at a point in my life when I was a big procrastinator. Thank you Mr.Pressfield! This book was a life changer.

title: Ego Is The Enemy
author: Ryan Holiday
notes: Ok, not as good as obstacle is the way.

title: Ego Is The Enemy
author: Ryan Holiday
notes: Ok, not as good as obstacle is the way.

title: Drive: The Surprising Truth About What Motivates Us
author: Daniel Pink
notes: I listened to this one on a long road trip to Northern Alberta and I don't remember anything useful from it.

title: Go Wild: Eat Fat, Run Free, Be Social, and Follow Evolution's Other Rules for Total Health and Well-being
author: Richard Manning & John J. Ratey MD
notes: I think this is the book that convinced me to start running on a regular basis. For that, it deserves a high rating.

title: Einstein: His Life and Universe
author: Walter Isaacson
notes: Learned a lot about this man. The picture of his desk after his death still haunts me.

title: So Good They Can't Ignore You: Why Skills Trump Passion in the Quest for Work You Love
author: Cal Newport
notes: Another good one from Cal Newport. I always this about this book when taking on any new endeavour.

title: The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck: A Counterintuitive Approach to Living a Good Life
author: Mark Manson
notes: This book was everywhere when it came out. It didn't live up to the hype for me. A lot of what Manson said was obvious stuff.

title: Deep Work: Rules for Focused Success in a Distracted World
author: Cal Newport
notes: I still struggle to work without distractions - it's so fucking hard. I think this is Cal's best book.

title: Smarter Faster Better: The Secrets of Being Productive in Life and Business
author: Charles Duhigg
notes: The one thing that has stuck with me through the years is the chapter on mental models. It's a topic that I want to do a deep dive on. Duhigg did a great job distilling productivity hacks in this book.

title: Smartcuts: How Hackers, Innovators, and Icons Accelerate Success
author: Shane Snow
notes: Nothing memorable about this book.

title: The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business
author: Charles Duhigg
notes: This book pre-dated atomic habits and it really opened my eyes to the science of how habits work. I read this one multiple times because it was so good. Highly recommended!

title: Blink
author: Malcolm Gladwell
notes: Don't remember a thing. The rating is based on the consistency of how good his books are.

title: Spark: The Revolutionary New Science of Exercise and the Brain
author: Eric Hagerman & John J. Ratey MD
notes: This book is the reason I exercise every single day.

title: Daily Rituals: How Artists Work
author: Mason Currey
notes: Interesting and entertaining.

title: Steve Jobs
author: Walter Isaacson
notes: Great book by Isaacson which is no surprise. Steve Jobs was a bit of an asshole, but you got to be a dick in those type of positions - and he was.

title: The Miracle Morning: The Not-So-Obvious Secret Guaranteed to Transform Your Life (Before 8AM)
author: Hal Elrod
notes: As I age, I do find myself getting up much earlier and it's great for getting things done. But when I first read this, I did not understand the science of sleep, so I was battling my physiology. Now I just go to bed early, like an old man.

title: The Game
author: Neil Strauss
notes: A very entertaining book about pickup artists.

title: Emotional Intelligence: Why It Can Matter More Than IQ
author: Daniel Goleman
notes: I read this a long time ago and don't remember much.

title: The 4-Hour Workweek
author: Tim Ferriss
notes: This book is responsible for a lot of what I do today. It influenced me to read a ton of other books and think smarter about work. I also listened to a lot of Tim's podcast episodes after reading this book and they are great too!

title: Thinking for a Change: 11 Ways Highly Successful People Approach Life and Work
author: John Maxwell
notes: This book reinforced my journaling habit.

title: You're It!: On Hiding, Seeking, and Being Found
author: Alan Watts
notes: An audible book of Watt's lectures. A great thinker and public speaker.

title: Outliers
author: Malcolm Gladwell
notes: Loved the stories about The Beatles and hockey players in Canada. Solid read.

title: We Learn Nothing
author: Tim Kreider
notes: I'm going to give this one another go because I recall liking it alot but forget a majority of it.

title: The Art Of Learning
author: Joshua Waitzkin
notes: Recommended by Tim Ferriss. I definitely felt dumb and undisciplined after listening to this. Josh seems to be best at learning new skills and then mastering them. Last I heard he was into freediving.

title: The Obstacle Is The Way
author: Ryan Holiday
notes: This was the book that introduced me to stoic philosophy and I gifted it to the guys in my wedding party. It set me on a different path, mentally.

title: The Tipping Point
author: Malcolm Gladwell
notes: I don't remember anything about this book. Only giving it a 7 because I have enjoyed all of Gladwell's work.

title: The 4-Hour Body
author: Tim Ferriss
notes: I'm a fan of Tim Ferriss. One thing I took from this book is the low-carb diet and cheat days - it helped a lot with getting my diet under control. I still recommend it to people trying to lose weight.

title: How To Win Friends And Influence People
author: Dale Carnegie
notes: This is one of self-development books that are highly recommended. I thought it was good, but as I get older, I don't care if I win friends and influence people. I suppose this would be a good one if you're extroverted or in sales.

title: Born Standing Up
author: Steve Martin
notes: Recommended by a friend. Interesting to hear the story of a comedian rising through the ranks and all the work that had to be done to get to the top.

title: The First 20 Hours
author: Josh Kaufman
notes: Not a fan of this one.

title: Status Anxiety
author: Alain De Bottom
notes: I read this a long time ago and do not remember anything. I do recall liking it.

title: The Personal MBA
author: Josh Kaufman
notes: Not sure why I read this - it was so dense. A lot of information that I will never use.

title: The Art Of Travel
author: Alain De Bottom
notes: Didn't like it. I'm probably too dumb to understand Botton.

title: Quiet Power
author: Susan Cane
notes: Didn't quite hit like Quiet.

title: Getting Things Done
author: David Allen
notes: Great book on productivity - I learned a lot!

title: The 7 Habits Of Highly Effective People
author: Stephen Covey
notes: This is another book that I can't recommend enough. A must read for everyone!

title: Digital Minimalism
author: Cal Newport
notes: Can't recall much about this book, but the title pretty much sums it up.

title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
author: Yuval Noah Harari
notes: A dense book, but interesting nonetheless. There was a chapter about currency that I still think about years after reading the book.

title: Talking to Strangers
author: Malcolm Gladwell
notes: Glad I picked this one up on Audible - it was part-book, part-podcast. A great read as always with Gladwell.

title: The Great Mental Models Volume 1
author: Shane Parrish
notes: I feel so dumb when I read about mental models and cognitive biases. That's probably the reason I haven't moved on to the other volumes. Very important concepts for clear thinking.

title: Do You Talk Funny?
author: David Nihill
notes: I enjoyed this book and I've been meaning to give it a reread. Picked this one up to improve my humorous speaking at Toastmasters.

title: Mindhunter
author: John Douglas & Mark Olshaker
notes: It started with the series on Netflix. I then went down the rabbit hole of Mindhunter books - they are so dam fascinating to me.

title: An Astronaut's Guide to Life on Earth
author: Chris Hadfield
notes: I didn't realize how much training it took to be an astronaut - super impressed! I will never forget the philosophy around aiming to be zero - great insight. Overall entertaining and a fun journey.

title: Emergency
author: Neil Strauss
notes: There was a sense of urgency to this book, but I found it boring.

title: Killer Across The Table
author: John Douglas & Mark Olshaker
notes: Very disturbing book. I felt ill at some parts.

title: The Cases That Haunt Us
author: John Douglas & Mark Olshaker
notes: As a consumer of true crime, this was an interesting read. The Jon Bene Ramsey case is baffling.

title: The Bomber Mafia
author: Malcolm Gladwell
notes: I'm a fan of war history, so this book was a treat. Great stories and philosophical thoughts about bombing in war time.

title: The Hobbit
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
notes: Probably my favorite fantasy book. I've read it multiple times over the years.

title: The Power Of Vulnerability
author: Brene Brown
notes: Don't recall much from this one, but I recall it being mostly lectures. Brene has a unique and charming personality.

title: On Writing
author: Stephen King
notes: I am a fan of King's work, but I didn't know much about him going in. This was definitely a treat. Had no idea he was hit by a car and survived. Overall, an entertaining read.

title: Models
author: Mark Manson
notes: Thought this was one intriguing, especially after reading The Game. Mark says be yourself, be honest, which is better than pickup artist method, although, it is less entertaining.

title: Caffeine
author: Michael Pollan
notes: Being a caffeine addict, I thought this was an interesting listen. It made me think about quitting coffee, but I don't think that is going to happen.

title: The Evil That Men Do
author: Roy Hazelwood
notes: A dive into the mind of predators. These FBI profiler books are fascinating and entertaining, yet scary as fuck.

title: Extreme Ownership
author: Jocko Willink & Leif Babin
notes: I listened to several podcast with Jocko before I finally made it to his book. The podcasts were memorable, but I do not recall anything from this book besides the title.

title: Endure
author: Cam Hanes
notes: Big fan of Cam Hanes - I love his attitude and work ethic. I thought the book was ok. It was good to learn a bit more about Cam's life, but I don't think he should have wasted any energy on addressing the haters.

title: Inside The Mind Of BTK
author: John Douglas & Johnny Dodd
notes: An insightful look into the mind of a man who was a notorious serial killer, but also a man that had a family and attended church. Appearances are often deceiving, and that's why this book scared the shit out of me.

title: Bittersweet
author: Susan Cain
notes: This one didn't resonate with me.

title: Never Finished
author: David Goggins
notes: Entertaining and motivating.

title: Man's Search For Meaning
author: Viktor Frankl
notes: I've been through this one a few times and recommended it to many friends. This is the type of the book that changes your perspective of the world. A must read for all humans.

title: Brave New World
author: Aldous Huxley
notes: A strange book. Hard not to compare the fictional world in the book to today's reality.

title: Chasing The Light
author: Oliver Stone
notes: A friend recommended this one. Pretty cool to hear how some iconic films were made.

title: Say Nothing
author: Patrick Radden Keefe
notes: A history I was completely unaware of. A fascinating story with a lot of interesting characters. Great writing too!

title: Shake Hands With The Devil
author: Romeo Dallaire
notes: Politics and genocide. I can't imagine having to live through such an atrocity.

title: Greenlights
author: Matthew McConaughey
notes: Entertaining. McConaughey's optimism is infectous.

title: Can’t Hurt Me
author: David Goggins
notes: Very motivating read when I was struggling with running. But now I find Goggins more comical than anything. Stay hard!

title: Atomic Habits
author: James Clear
notes: I have read this one several times and recommend it the most. It has helped me in countless ways.

title: The Psychology of Money
author: Morgan Housel
notes: Another book I have read more than once. I would say this is once of the best books on money out there.

title: The Compound Effect
author: Darren Hardy
notes: Kinda felt like a sales pitch, but a lot of good practical advice. I do agree with the concept of tracking and measuring everything you do. Otherwise, you can't fix what you can't measure. This book validated some of my weird habits around tracking my personal life.

title: Do Hard Things
author: Steve Magness
notes: A book on the benefits of doing hard things. Kinda felt like a lot of this stuff was obvious. Probably read it to validate my running.

title: With the Old Breed
author: E.B. Sledge
notes: Read this while on vacation in Mexico. How it made me feel like a weak man. Haunting account of fighting in the pacific
